title: 112_s3456
content: The "Child Protection Act of 2012" enhances penalties for possession of child pornography. The "Child Protection Act of 2012" increases penalties for possession of child pornography, including fines and imprisonment for up to 20 years for those involved with prepubescent minors or minors under 12 years old. Additionally, the act includes provisions for the protection of child witnesses. The "Child Protection Act of 2012" enhances penalties for child pornography possession, with up to 20 years imprisonment for offenses involving prepubescent minors or those under 12. It also includes measures to protect child witnesses, such as issuing protective orders against harassment or intimidation. The court may issue a protective order to prevent intimidation of minor witnesses or victims in Federal criminal cases. An emergency protective order can be issued in advance if necessary, with a hearing to follow within 14 days. The court can issue protective orders to safeguard minor witnesses or victims in Federal criminal cases. Violating such orders can result in fines, imprisonment for up to 5 years, or both. The term "course of conduct" refers to a series of acts indicating a continuity of purpose. The term 'harassment' refers to serious conduct causing emotional distress with no legitimate purpose. 'Intimidation' is serious conduct causing fear with no legitimate purpose. 'Immediate family member' includes grandchildren. 'Restricted personal information' is defined in section 119. The term 'serious act' refers to threatening, retaliatory, harassing, or violent conduct likely to influence a victim or witness in a Federal criminal case. A 'specific person' includes a victim, witness, or their immediate family member. The distribution of personal information online about a specific person is presumed to serve no legitimate purpose unless authorized by that person or for news reporting purposes. The United States Sentencing Commission will review and amend sentencing guidelines to provide an additional penalty increase for certain offenses involving violations of specific sections of the United States Code. The United States Sentencing Commission will amend sentencing guidelines to increase penalties for offenses involving violations of specific sections of the United States Code, including causing physical harm to a person under 18 to obstruct justice. SEC. 4. SUBPOENAS TO FACILITATE THE ARREST OF FUGITIVE SEX OFFENDERS. SEC. 4 amends Section 3486(a)(1) of title 18, United States Code, to include unregistered sex offenders being pursued by the United States Marshals Service. Section 3486(a) of title 18, United States Code is amended to define the term 'sex offender' as an individual required to register under the Sex Offender Registration and Notification Act. Technical and conforming amendments are made to various paragraphs within the code. Additionally, Section 566(e)(1) of title 28, United States Code is amended regarding judicial subpoenas. Section 566(e)(1) of title 28, United States Code is amended to allow for the issuance of administrative subpoenas for investigating unregistered sex offenders. SEC. 5 increases funding for ICAC training courses from $2,000,000 to $4,000,000. SEC. 6 establishes a National Coordinator for Child Exploitation Prevention and Interdiction in the Senior Executive Service. SEC. 7 amends the PROTECT Our Children Act of 2008 to allocate $60,000,000 for fiscal years 2014-2018 to ICAC task forces. SEC. 8 clarifies the definition of "high-priority suspect" in the Act. SEC. 9 requires a report to Congress. The Attorney General must report to Congress within 90 days of the Act's enactment on the progress of establishing the National Internet Crimes Against Children Data System as mandated by the PROTECT Our Children Act of 2008.
